articles.headline: House Jan. 6 Committee Signals It Will Issue Criminal Referrals
articles.snippet: Speaking before a formal decision had been made, Representative Bennie Thompson said his panel had not yet agreed on who would be the subject of the referrals or what the charges would be.
articles.abstract: Speaking before a formal decision had been made, Representative Bennie Thompson said his panel had not yet agreed on who would be the subject of the referrals or what the charges would be.
articles.lead_paragraph: Representative Bennie Thompson, the chairman of the House panel investigating the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol, on Tuesday gave the strongest signal yet that the panel planned to make criminal referrals to the Justice Department, raising the prospect of a history-making finding that former President Donald J. Trump’s efforts to cling to power after he lost the 2020 election amounted to a crime.
articles.byline: By Michael S. Schmidt, Luke Broadwater and Alexandra Berzon

articles.headline: China Eases ‘Zero Covid’ Restrictions in Victory for Protesters
articles.snippet: Beijing’s costly policy of lockdowns has pummeled the world’s second-largest economy and set off mass public protests that were a rare challenge to China’s leader, Xi Jinping.
articles.abstract: Beijing’s costly policy of lockdowns has pummeled the world’s second-largest economy and set off mass public protests that were a rare challenge to China’s leader, Xi Jinping.
articles.lead_paragraph: Over the past three years, China’s top leader, Xi Jinping, staked his legitimacy on “zero Covid,” making it an ideological campaign aimed at demonstrating the superiority of centralized control over democratic rule. He declared a “people’s war” against the coronavirus that used lockdowns and quarantines to eliminate infections.
articles.byline: By Keith Bradsher, Chang Che and Amy Chang Chien

articles.headline: Twitter’s Rivals Try to Capitalize on Musk-Induced Chaos
articles.snippet: New start-ups and other social platforms sense opportunity as Twitter grapples with changes from Elon Musk, its new owner.
articles.abstract: New start-ups and other social platforms sense opportunity as Twitter grapples with changes from Elon Musk, its new owner.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Last month, employees at Meta, which owns Facebook and Instagram, joined a virtual brainstorming session to discuss how to build the next Twitter.

articles.headline: Germany Arrests 25 Suspected of Planning to Overthrow Government
articles.snippet: Among those detained were a German prince, a former far-right member of Parliament, an active soldier and former members of the police and elite special forces.
articles.abstract: Among those detained were a German prince, a former far-right member of Parliament, an active soldier and former members of the police and elite special forces.
articles.lead_paragraph: BERLIN — The plan was to storm the German Capitol, arrest lawmakers and execute the chancellor. A prince descended from German nobility would take over as the new head of state, and a former far-right member of Parliament would be put in charge of a national purge.
articles.byline: By Katrin Bennhold and Erika Solomon

articles.headline: A Pastor and Politician Who Sees Voting as a Form of Prayer
articles.snippet: Raphael Warnock, a son of Savannah public housing who rose to become Georgia’s first Black senator, secured a full six-year term and a spot among Democrats’ rising stars.
articles.abstract: Raphael Warnock, a son of Savannah public housing who rose to become Georgia’s first Black senator, secured a full six-year term and a spot among Democrats’ rising stars.
articles.lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

articles.headline: Supreme Court Seems Split Over Case That Could Transform Federal Elections
articles.snippet: The justices are considering whether to adopt the “independent state legislature” theory, which could give state lawmakers nearly unchecked power over federal elections.
articles.abstract: The justices are considering whether to adopt the “independent state legislature” theory, which could give state lawmakers nearly unchecked power over federal elections.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court seemed splintered on Wednesday about whether to adopt a legal theory that would radically reshape how federal elections are conducted, giving state legislatures largely unchecked power to set all sorts of election rules and draw congressional maps warped by partisan gerrymandering.

articles.headline: The ‘SPAC King’ Is Over It
articles.snippet: Chamath Palihapitiya, once a relentless cheerleader of special purpose acquisition companies, blames the Federal Reserve for the end of SPAC mania.
articles.abstract: Chamath Palihapitiya, once a relentless cheerleader of special purpose acquisition companies, blames the Federal Reserve for the end of SPAC mania.
articles.lead_paragraph: Not long ago, Chamath Palihapitiya could be called the Jim Cramer of SPACs.

articles.headline: Why Losing to Meta in Court May Still Be a Win for Regulators
articles.snippet: As the Federal Trade Commission prepares to face off in court against Meta over a V.R. start-up deal, the agency is testing a novel argument as part of a strategy to push antitrust law.
articles.abstract: As the Federal Trade Commission prepares to face off in court against Meta over a V.R. start-up deal, the agency is testing a novel argument as part of a strategy to push antitrust law.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Biden’s antitrust regulators have adopted a mantra: In order to win, they need to be willing to lose.

articles.headline: India Chases Clean Energy, but Economic Goals Put Coal First
articles.snippet: “I will not compromise on the availability of power,” India’s energy minister has declared in defense of fossil fuel use, which is heavily subsidized.
articles.abstract: “I will not compromise on the availability of power,” India’s energy minister has declared in defense of fossil fuel use, which is heavily subsidized.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the shadow of a retired coal-fired power plant in India’s capital, Meena Devi tries to make her family home — four brick walls with a tin roof — a safe place to breathe.
articles.byline: By Emily Schmall and Clifford Krauss
